newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Telstra to trial Internet telephone gadget.
newsitem.headline: Telstra to trial Internet telephone gadget.

text.p: Telstra Corp Ltd said on Friday it plans to trial technology which will allow customers with one telephone line to receive and make calls on their personal computer while they are using the Internet.
Telstra said it will trial the voice-over-Internet Protocol technology (IP) developed by NetSpeak Corp.

"A telephone call that would ordinarily have been blocked can now be delivered to an Internet user as if the customer had a second line," said John Rolland, general manager of Telstra Big Pond, the group's Internet Service Provider.
"We also expect that this technology will support 'Icon Calling' services in the future which enable customers to click on icons on web pages to initiate calls," Rolland said.
However, a Telstra spokesman said the company has no plans at this stage to offer Internet telephony services.

"Today, if a customer is connected to an Internet Service Provider (ISP) using the telephone network, anyone trying to call would get a busy signal. With the Telstra/NetSpeak technology, the call can be rerouted to the ISP and presented to the Internet user through special software running on the user's PC," Rolland said in a statement.
NetSpeak's Asia-Pacific Region managing director Peter Clark said in the same statement the trial was significant in the evolution of convergence of voice and data networks.
